case_name: State of Maharashtra v. First Grade Clerks (respondents)

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 259 and 260 of 1964 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 259 and 260 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated October 27, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 42 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated October 27, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 42 of 1961.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 226 filed by three First Grade clerks attached to offices of Collectors of Wardha, Bhandara and Chanda districts.

anchor.surface_text: a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, filed by three First Grade clerks attached to the offices of the Collectors of Wardha, Bhandara and Chanda districts. They are the three respondents in this appeal.

facts.text: Petition originally filed by two respondents as Secretary and Member of Ministerial Services Associations, Wardha and Bhandara, treated as personal petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The petition in the High Court was originally filled by two of these respondents as Secretary and Member of the Ministerial Services Associations, Wardha and Bhandara respectively but they were treated as petitions on their personal behalf.

facts.text: Petitioners sought writ of mandamus for equation of First Grade clerks posts with Aval Karkuns under ss. 115 and 116 of States Reorganization Act, 1956 and Allocated Government Servants Rules 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners asked for a writ of mandamus against the Government of Bombay for the equation of their posts with Aval Karkuns in the State of Bombay later the State of Maharashtra under ss. 115 and 116 of the States Reorganization Act, 1956 (Act 37 of 1956) read with the Allocated Government Servants (Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances) Rules 1957.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. SR INT 1057/VI dated October 21, 1957 ordered First Grade clerks posts in Deputy Commissioners offices to continue on Rs. 80-5-130 scale.

anchor.surface_text: Government Resolution No. SR INT 1057/VI dated October 21, 1957, together with Item No. 8 and Note 5 of the Statement accompanying that resolution, should be quashed... By that Resolution the posts of First Grade clerks in the Deputy Commissioners offices were ordered to companytinue on the existing scale of pay of Rs. 80-5-130.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. SR INT/2159/21365-F dated October 12, 1960 fixed pay scale of Rs. 100-8-140 for First Grade clerks posts from May 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Government Resolution No. SR INT/2159/21365-F dated October 12, 1960 should be quashed inasmuch as it fixed new scales of pay (Rs. 100-8-140) for the posts held by the petitioners from May 1, 1960

facts.text: States Reorganisation Act took effect on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: from November 1, 1956 on which date the States reorganisation under the above Act took effect.

facts.text: Bombay High Court rejected petitioners' contention on equivalence of posts but accepted new pay scales from November 1, 1956 instead of May 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention of the petitioners as to equivalence but accepted their companytention that the new scales of pay ought to companymence on November 1, 1956 and number May 1, 1960 as ordered by Government.

facts.text: High Court issued appropriate writs for pay scales from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appropriate writs to effectuate the latter part of the order of the High Court issued.

facts.text: High Court certified case under Art. 132(1) and all three clauses of Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, certified the case under Art. 132 (1) and curiously enough under all the three clauses of Art. 133 of the Constitution

facts.text: States reorganised in 1956 requiring division and integration of services under Part X, ss. 115 and 116 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: After the reorganisation of the States in 1956 it was necessary to divide and integrate the Services in the various States affected by the reorganisation. Part X of the Act, particularly ss. 115 and 1 16 dealt with the manner

facts.text: Allocated Government Servants (Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances) Rules 1957 made by Government of Bombay under s.115 and Art. 309.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the powers companyferred by S. 115 of the Act read with Art. 309 of the Constitution, the Allocated Government Servants (Absorption, etc.) Rules were made by the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Dispute governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The present dispute is governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules and we shall proceed to companysider them.

facts.text: First Grade clerks pay scale immediately before November 1, 1956 was Rs. 80-5-130.

anchor.surface_text: The scale of pay which they enjoyed immediately before November 1, 1956 was Rs. 80-5-

facts.text: No equivalent post declared for First Grade clerks or decided unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: the allocated Government servant who immediately before the 1st November, 1956 held at a post to which Government has number declared an equivalent post or has decided that it is number necessary to declare an equivalent post

facts.text: Duties of Aval Karkuns in former Bombay State entirely different from First Grade clerks.

anchor.surface_text: numberequivalent post was found as the duties of Aval Karkuns in the former Bombay State were entirely different from those which First Grade clerks performed.

facts.text: Bombay High Court decided against petitioners on assimilation to Aval Karkuns.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the First Grade clerks ought to be assimilated to Aval Karkuns was decided against the three original petitioners by the High Court

facts.text: Petitioners contended discrimination due to no equivalent post assigned and rule 12 discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: They companytend that Government was bound to find an equivalent post for them... by number assigning them to an equivalent post they have been discriminated against and that rule 12 which enables that a post need number be equated to an equivalent post is discriminatory.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no discrimination in not equating posts or in rule 12.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment neither submission is companyrect. There is numberquestion of discrimination... Nor do we think that there was discrimination in doing so or Rule 12 under which it was done was discriminatory.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court order that pay scales commence from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the order of the High Court cancelling the date May 1, 1960 as the starting. point of the new scales of pay and fixing November 1, 1956 as. the date of start must be upheld.

facts.text: State Government's appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal of the, State Government must, therefore, stand dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioners' appeal in CA No. 260 of 1964 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants in Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1964 must, therefore, fail.

a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, filed by three First Grade clerks attached to the offices of the Collectors of Wardha, Bhandara and Chanda districts. They are the three respondents in this appeal.

The petitioners asked for a writ of mandamus against the Government of Bombay for the equation of their posts with Aval Karkuns in the State of Bombay later the State of Maharashtra under ss. 115 and 116 of the States Reorganization Act, 1956 (Act 37 of 1956) read with the Allocated Government Servants (Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances) Rules 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Government Resolution No. SR INT 1057/VI dated October 21, 1957, together with Item No. 8 and Note 5 of the Statement accompanying that resolution, should be quashed... By that Resolution the posts of First Grade clerks in the Deputy Commissioners offices were ordered to continue on the existing scale of pay of Rs. 80-5-130.

concepts.unlisted_description: Remedy sought to quash government resolution

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners asked for a writ of mandamus against the Government of Bombay for the equation of their posts with Aval Karkuns in the State of Bombay later the State of Maharashtra under ss. 115 and 116 of the States Reorganization Act, 1956 (Act 37 of 1956) read with the Allocated Government Servants (Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances) Rules 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The present dispute is governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules and we shall proceed to consider them. ... Provided that if under these rules the pay- scale applicable is the pay-scale prescribed by Government, the allocated Government servant shall, if he belongs to a category referred to in clauses (a), (b) and (c) of the first proviso to rule 10 above, have the option to exercise the elections referred to in the said rule 10 in the manner and within the period prescribed in rule 11.

anchor.surface_text: The present dispute is governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules and we shall proceed to consider them. ... the pay-scale which would have been applicable had the allocated Government servant continued in the service of the former State or such other pay-scale as Government may by general or special orders prescribe

concepts.interpretation: Applicable where no equivalent post declared; power to prescribe pay-scale must operate from November 1, 1956; not discriminatory; for special treatment of odd cases

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: us that some existing posts companyld number simply be equated with posts in the principal successor State. They had to be treated on an independent f

concepts.unlisted_description: Pay-scale where no equivalent post declared

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2 of these Rules gives definition of Allocated Government servant and Equivalent post. By allocated Government servant is meant a person allotted for service in the new State of Bombay under the provisions of s. 115 of the Act including servants of the former Bombay State who continue in the service of the new State of Bombay. Equivalent post means (a) a post in the former State of Bombay, or (b) any other post which is declared as equivalent to a post

arguments.claim: No question of discrimination in not equating posts as duties different and rule 12 valid for odd cases

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment neither submission is correct. There is no question of discrimination... Nor do we think that there was discrimination in doing so or Rule 12 under which it was done was discriminatory.

arguments.claim: No compulsion in ss. 115 and 116 to equate every post

anchor.surface_text: There is also nothing in ss. 115 and 116 of the Reorganisation Act which compels equivalence in every case.

arguments.claim: Rule 10 proviso 'except where Government otherwise directs' permits departure from scales in (i) and (ii) but not from date November 1, 1956

anchor.surface_text: The words of the rule except where Government otherwise directs were not intended to change the date on which the scales of pay were to come into operation, namely, November 1, 1956, but to enable Government to make special orders which were not in accordance with (i) and (ii) of the rule.

arguments.claim: Rule 12 non-obstante clause enables special cases but pay scales operate from November 1, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Rule 12 also provides that, notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing rules... Here again, the old pay scale or the new pay-scale... commences on November 1, 1956.

arguments.claim: Other rules (14-19, 23) consistently fix November 1, 1956 as pay scale dateline

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is apparent if we take into account the provisions of the other rules. Every one of the rules, such as rules 14 to 19 including all the sub-rules and rule 23, mention over and over again that the new scales of pay shall be as on or from November 1, 1956.

holdings.text: The First Grade clerks ought not to be assimilated to Aval Karkuns as duties are entirely different and no equivalent post declared.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of First Grade clerks in the Collectorate no equivalent post was found as the duties of Aval Karkuns in the former Bombay State were entirely different from those which First Grade clerks performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duties differ substantially; government decided no equivalent post needed under rules.

holdings.text: There is no obligation under ss. 115 and 116 of States Reorganisation Act to declare equivalent post in every case.

anchor.surface_text: There is also nothing in ss. 115 and 116 of the Reorganisation Act which compels equivalence in every case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions do not compel equivalence; allows for cases where posts do not fit.

holdings.text: No discrimination in not assigning equivalent post or in operation of rule 12; rule 12 provides for special treatment of odd cases and is not discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment neither submission is correct. There is no question of discrimination... Nor do we think that there was discrimination in doing so or Rule 12 under which it was done was discriminatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discrimination requires available equivalent post not used; rule 12 handles multifarious posts without equivalence.

holdings.text: Under rule 10, 'except where Government otherwise directs' permits departure from specific scales in (i) and (ii) but not from operative date of November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the rule except where Government otherwise directs were not intended to change the date on which the scales of pay were to come into operation, namely, November 1, 1956, but to enable Government to make special orders which were not in accordance with (i) and (ii) of the rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual placement and harmonious construction with other rules fix November 1, 1956 as dateline; consistent across rules 14-19,23.

holdings.text: Under rule 12 non-obstante clause, government power to prescribe pay-scale for posts without equivalent must operate from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 12 also provides that, notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing rules... Here again, the old pay scale or the new pay-scale... commences on November 1, 1956. The power which is conferred on Government to prescribe new pay-scale must be exercised from November 1, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante enables special cases outside rule 10 but tied to November 1, 1956 dateline; purposive to integrate from reorganisation date.

holdings.text: Revised pay scales for First Grade clerks must commence from November 1, 1956, not May 1, 1960; High Court order upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the order of the High Court cancelling the date May 1, 1960 as the starting point of the new scales of pay and fixing November 1, 1956 as the date of start must be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 10 and 12 mandate pay scales from reorganisation date; government resolutions fixing later date invalid.

holdings.text: Petitioners' contention in CA No. 260 of 1964 on equivalence fails; State appeal in CA No. 259 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants in Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1964 must, therefore, fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on rejection of equivalence and discrimination claims under relevant rules and Act.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld: rejection of equation of First Grade clerks with Aval Karkuns posts confirmed; new pay scales Rs. 100-8-140 to take effect from November 1, 1956 instead of May 1, 1960. Both appeals (C.A. Nos. 259 and 260 of 1964) dismissed.
